M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a Court may modify a judgment relative to custody or parenting time “upon a showing that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.”

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Similarly, **M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, applies the same standard to modifications concerning nonmarital children, emphasizing best interests and material change.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The Court’s primary concern under **M.G.L. c. 208, § 31** and related statutes is the **best interests of the child**, which now require modification of the existing parenting schedule.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that changes affecting a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute a material change in circumstances.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with initial custody determination and a removal request, not with modification of an existing custody order based on a material change in circumstances. Nowhere does the court discuss what constitutes a ‘material change’ or link changes in a parent’s availability or caregiving ability to that standard. Therefore, it does not establish or affirm the proposition about material change in circumstances in Massachusetts case law.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that changes affecting a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute a material change in circumstances.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion does address the concept of a “material and substantial change in circumstances” required for custody modification, but it does not hold that changes in a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child automatically constitute such a change. Instead, the court finds that the mother’s hectic work schedule and use of childcare, and later improvements in her schedule, do not warrant modification, and concludes there was no post‑divorce change of sufficient magnitude to justify changing custody. Thus, the case cuts against the claimed proposition rather than supporting it.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude’… We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification.… There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements…”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that changes affecting a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute a material change in circumstances.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is a custody decision focused on the impact of domestic violence and the need for explicit findings about that impact. It does not discuss or apply the standard for modification of an existing custody order, nor does it address what constitutes a material change in circumstances based on a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child. Thus, it is not authority for the proposition about material change in circumstances.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that changes affecting a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute a material change in circumstances.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion is about an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not a modification proceeding requiring a showing of material or substantial change in circumstances. The court expressly declines to apply or discuss the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard from § 20 and instead focuses entirely on the best-interests framework and statutory factors for initial custody. It therefore does not address, much less hold, that changes in a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute a material change in circumstances.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that changes affecting a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute a material change in circumstances.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the standard for a removal request under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint physical custody context and frames the inquiry purely as whether removal is in the child’s best interests. It does not discuss modification standards generally or characterize a change in a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child as a ‘material change in circumstances.’ The only explicit reference to ‘substantial change in circumstances’ appears in a quoted ALI Principles passage, not as a statement of Massachusetts case law, and is tied specifically to relocation, not to parental availability changes in general.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: “(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] … .” The court then applies a best-interests standard to the removal request under G. L. c. 208, § 30.

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that changes affecting a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute a material change in circumstances.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: The case is an alimony modification case and does not concern child custody or material changes affecting a parent’s availability or ability to care for a child. The opinion discusses ‘material change of circumstances’ only in the context of modifying alimony obligations based on retirement and financial changes between former spouses. It therefore does not establish or apply any rule that changes in a parent’s caregiving availability constitute a material change for custody or parenting issues.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “‘To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’ Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that changes affecting a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute a material change in circumstances.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best interests standard and factors relevant to an initial custody determination between two legal parents, including stability of each home and each parent’s behavior and work schedule. It does not address the distinct legal standard for *modifying* an existing custody order based on a “material change in circumstances,” nor does it articulate a rule that changes in a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute such a material change. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about material change in circumstances in Massachusetts case law.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent. See Adoption of Kali, supra at 843, 847 (stability and flexible work schedule); Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 230-231 (1998)… Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 557 (1980) (denial of custody where home was not ‘settled’ and child would be cared for by multiple providers rather than parent).”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that changes affecting a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute a material change in circumstances.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion is an adoption/care-and-protection decision focused on best interests of the child and comparative adoptive placements, not on modification of custody or visitation based on a “material change in circumstances.” Nowhere does the court discuss what constitutes a material change in circumstances or link changes in a parent’s availability or caregiving ability to such a standard. Thus, this case does not establish or affirm the specific material-change principle described in the proposition.

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that changes affecting a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute a material change in circumstances.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion is a care-and-protection / permanent custody decision focused on parental unfitness, evidentiary standards, and inferences from a failure to testify. It does not discuss or apply a “material change in circumstances” standard, nor does it analyze changes in a parent’s availability or caregiving ability as a threshold material-change question. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that such changes constitute a material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.relevant_excerpt: “A decision to remove children permanently from the home of their natural parents must be supported by clear and convincing evidence that the parents are currently unfit to care and provide for their children…. The court is permitted to assess prognostic evidence derived from prior patterns of parental neglect or misconduct in determining future fitness and the likelihood of harm to the child.”

Zullo v. Goguen, 423 Mass. 679 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that changes affecting a parent’s availability or ability to care for the child constitute a material change in circumstances.
Zullo v. Goguen, 423 Mass. 679 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns service requirements and appellate review procedures for abuse prevention orders under G.L. c. 209A. It does not involve child custody, parenting time, or standards for modification such as material changes in a parent’s availability or ability to care for a child. Therefore, it does not address or establish the proposition about what constitutes a material change in circumstances in Massachusetts family law.
Zullo v. Goguen, 423 Mass. 679 (1996).relevant_excerpt: We turn to our second concern, which relates to the proper procedure for seeking review of a G. L. c. 209A order. Our prior cases have recognized G. L. c. 211, § 3, as the only available route to obtain such review... we conclude that, henceforth, review of orders pursuant to G. L. c. 209A should not be initiated by petition under G. L. c. 211, § 3, but rather by the filing of an appeal in the Appeals Court.
